awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Quantifying the response of rivers and floodplains to changes in climate and land use
awd_abstract_narration:
A thorough understanding of how rivers respond to changes in climate and land use is fundamental to decrease impact from flooding, to design and maintain structures such as water intakes and bridges, to protect and restore river ecosystems, and to manage water resources in general.  This research is specifically designed to quantify how river channels and the adjoining floodplains respond to natural and anthropogenic changes in climate and land use. Educational aspects of this project are designed with formal learning activities (field work at the Congaree National Park, design and construction of experimental installations for education, and the introduction of a new undergraduate level course on sustainable river engineering practices into the curriculum) to build an educational environment using collaborative learning pedagogy in which students learn how to work in a diverse, interdisciplinary, and international group.  These education aspects are targeted to prepare the next generation of engineers to tackle scientific and professional problems associated with water resources management.  Informal learning activities, such as the creation of an interactive digital platform for the Congaree National Park and summer camps for high school students, will inform the general public on the effects that humans and a changing climate can have on the environment in which they live in. 

The main scientific objective of the research is to advance knowledge on river morphodynamics, and enable quantitative prediction of changes in channel geometry and pattern observed in the field.  It is hypothesized that the mode of bed material (sand or gravel) transport and the exchange of sediment between the river and the floodplain are key processes controlling river morphodynamics at spatial scales ranging from tens to hundreds of kilometers and at temporal scales ranging from a few decades to several centuries.  This hypothesis will be tested with laboratory experiments to gain insight into the role of sediment grain size on channel morphology, mathematical modeling to provide physics-based quantitative tools on river morphodynamics, and fieldwork to characterize the annual variability of channel geometry on a reach of the Congaree River in the Congaree River National Park, USA, that has been responding to changes in hydrology and land use since the 1700s.  Additional field sites that are being affected by human-induced changes in land use will also be considered.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Predicting how river geometry (width, depth, slope, planform shape) varies in response to changes in climate or human activities such as construction of dams and levees, agricultural practices, mining and urbanization is a long studied but still unresolved problem. Understanding how rivers evolve over few decades is important to protect riparian communities and ecosystems from episodic floods, design and maintain infrastructure, predict fate and transport of sediment, nutrient and contaminants. Modeling this change, however, is complex because of the multitude of processes involved.
Central hypothesis of the project was that the type of sediment transport, i.e. near the channel bed or in the water column), and the sediment exchange between the main channel and the surrounding areas are key processes controlling river geometry over several 10s of kilometers. This hypothesis was tested with the aid of laboratory experiments, field work and numerical modeling.


Planform shapes, i.e. river shapes seen from an airplane, are generally classified as meandering or single thread, when there is one channel flowing in a floodplain, or braided when channels (braids) bifurcate and merge around islands.


The role of sediment transport type in braided rivers was investigated with laboratory experiments conducted with 0.2 mm sand and 0.6 mm sand. The 0.2 mm sand was considered representative of sediment that can be transported near the bed and and in suspension (sand), the 0.6 mm sand was used to model sediment that is only transported near the bed (gravel). Experiments were conducted with constant flow of water and supply of sediment and revealed that in response to an increase in water flow the coarse channel became, as expected, milder (smaller slope) and the number of braids decreased. The response of the fine sediment channel was unexpected as the number of braids and the slope increased. We interpret this result as an indication that, in response to a change in water flow, island geometry changed and this change caused the number of braids to increase and, consequently, the bed slope to increase to transport the sediment supplied from upstream. In summary, the experiments revealed that a change in water flow can alter the sediment exchange between island and braids in braided rivers and the type of change vary with sediment size (and thus transport mode). Numerical modeling was used to assess the impact of a river restoration project on the Buech River, France, downstream of a dam where gravel was added to reduce erosion and help improve the aquatic habitat for endangered fishes. Model results showed that while an increase in sediment supply downstream of the dam can indeed help reduce erosion, an increase in flow releases is necessary to restore a healthy habitat.

The role of sediment transport and fluxes in meandering rivers was studied with field work and numerical modeling. Field work was conducted along the Congaree River from Columbia, South Carolina, to the confluence with the Wateree River ~80 km downstream. Channel geometry was surveyed and compared with the geometry measured in 1884 during a hydrographic survey. This comparison revealed that there has been no significant change in channel geometry in the past 140 years notwithsanding the construction of a dam upstream of Columbia. In other words, the dam did not alter frequency and magnitude of frequent floods, and thus did not have a strong impact on channel geometry. Mesurements of channel bed level also showed that the Congaree River slope may be slowly increasing in response to changes in hydrology that happened 16,000 years ago at the end of the last glaciation. Measurements of thickness and grain size of sediment deposited on the floodplain surprisingly indicate that the network of floodplain channels and connected depressions effectively transport sand in the floodplain interior challenging existing models of floodplain sedimentation. Widening of the Minnesota River, MN, main channel caused by changes in flood frequency due to artificial drainage was modeled numerically. This modeling exercise revealed that modeling fluxes of sediment between the river and the floodplain due to bank movement and deposition of sediment on the floodplain is critical to reproduce changes in width.

The educational component of the proposal was centered on training graduate and undergraduate student to face the scientific and professional challenges associated with sustainable environmental and water resources management. During 6 project years, 17 undergraduate student, 7 graduate students and 1 post-doc were supported by the project and trained in a multidisciplinary group. Eleven undergradaute students trained during this project decided to pursue a gradaute education. All students that decided to seek a professional career are employed in civil engineering companies.
